thread.title: 5 things you should never say at the office, according to management experts
thread.title_full: 5 things you should never say at the office, according to management experts | OregonLive.com

author: Douglas Perry | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: 5 things you should never say at the office, according to management experts
text:
It's not fair that I have to write this article. I'm only doing it because this is the way it's always been done.
Well ... I've just damaged my career, according to TalentSmart cofounder Travis Bradberry .
The psychologist, author and management consultant wrote in a LinkedIn posting that using certain phrases in the office "instantly change the way people see you and can forever cast you in a negative light."
Your boss and coworkers probably won't consciously think less of you when you say these phrases, but raises, promotions and invitations to lunch might not be as forthcoming as you think they should be, The Independent wrote in an analysis of Bradberry's work. So here are the Top 5 phrases to avoid saying at the office at all costs:
It's not fair.
No kidding. Get used to it -- and stop complaining about the obvious to everyone else. Saying something isn't fair makes you seem "immature and na√Øve," Bradberry wrote.
This is the way it's always been done.
Ah, yes, the clarion call of the innovator. Declaring that something should be done a certain way because it's always been done that way "not only makes you sound lazy and resistant to change, but it could make your boss wonder why you haven't tried to improve things on your own," The Independent writes.
No problem.
This phrase apparently gives the impression that you don't want to do whatever it is you've just agreed to do. Bradberry recommends using actual positive language, such as: "I'll be happy to take care of that."
This may be a silly idea/I'm going to ask a stupid question.
When you start with one of these phrases, you sound weak and unsure of yourself. Donald Trump would fire you in a second. Managers sometimes say there are no stupid questions, but they secretly know there are. Don't put the thought in their head. Ask questions or float ideas from a place of strength: get across that you're gathering more information or brainstorming while well on your way to solving whatever problem is at hand.
This will only take a minute.
What's wrong with that? After all, we're all supposed to be fast and nimble workers these days. The Independent says that "unless you're literally going to complete the task in 60 seconds," saying this makes you appear less competent, like someone who rushes through tasks.
There, I'm done with the article. That wasn't so bad after all. And it only took a minute. Oops . Actually, it took ... a while . But not too long. Or something.
Ridding yourself of bad workplace phrases is harder than it appears. If you found the above advice useful, be aware that Bradberry isn't done. Find out more phrases and behavior you should avoid at the office .
